results.abstract: Matthew Brzezinski article on Slavutich, Ukraine, new town specially built for workers at nuclear power plant in Chernobyl, who make ten times the average national wage; photos (M)

headline.main: The Silver Lining in Chernobyl's Cloud

results.snippet: There was a time when Leonid Aniskin was frightened of radiation. But that was before he went to work at the Chernobyl nuclear power station. He still remembers his first day on the job. It was in 1987, a little over a year after an explosion had...
results.lead_paragraph: There was a time when Leonid Aniskin was frightened of radiation. But that was before he went to work at the Chernobyl nuclear power station. He still remembers his first day on the job. It was in 1987, a little over a year after an explosion had ripped the roof off the plant's fourth reactor block. ''The trees in the forest behind the station had all died,'' he recalls. ''The pine needles had turned red and dropped off.'' Soldiers were burying the radioactive tree trunks when he arrived for his first shift. Everywhere he looked there were men in masks and dark rubber suits, and orange bulldozers scraping away the contaminated soil.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis is set to begin 11-day mission to outfit International Space Station for arrival of its first permanent residents in Nov; flight will be first of surge of 15 station-related missions by American and Russian rockets planned for coming year to greatly increase station's size and functions; National Aeronautics and Space Administration managers are giving shuttle narrow window of time for takeoff, when ground position is best aligned with space station's orbit, to save fuel (M)

headline.main: Launching of Shuttle Will Begin Push to Complete Space Outpost

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis is set to head for the International Space Station on Friday, beginning an intense push to finish the long-delayed orbital research outpost.    The Atlantis and its seven-member crew are to blast off at 8:45 a.m.  Eastern...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis is set to head for the International Space Station on Friday, beginning an intense push to finish the long-delayed orbital research outpost. The Atlantis and its seven-member crew are to blast off at 8:45 a.m. Eastern time, beginning an 11-day mission to outfit the growing station for the arrival of its first permanent residents in November. The flight begins a surge of 15 station-related missions by American and Russian rockets during the coming year, which will greatly increase the station's size and functions.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis docks with International Space Station; Edward Lu, American astronaut, and Russian counterpart Yuri Malenchenko take spacewalk to lay cable and erect boom for compass; photo (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Shuttle Docks at Station; Long Spacewalk Begins

results.snippet: Ending a two-day chase, the space shuttle Atlantis sped alongside the International Space Station early Sunday and latched on.    Early this morning, Edward Lu, an American astronaut, and Yuri Malenchenko, a Russian cosmonaut, floated out of the...
results.lead_paragraph: Ending a two-day chase, the space shuttle Atlantis sped alongside the International Space Station early Sunday and latched on. Early this morning, Edward Lu, an American astronaut, and Yuri Malenchenko, a Russian cosmonaut, floated out of the shuttle for a 110-foot walk outside of the station.

results.abstract: Dr Edward Lu and Col Yuri Malenchenko leave space shuttle Atlantis and make grueling climb up International Space Station to lay cable and install boom for navigation unit on station's exterior; walk, 110 feet from Atlantis's cargo bay, is farthest distance any NASA spacewalker has ventured while tethered; photo (M)
results.snippet: An American astronaut and a Russian cosmonaut drifted out of the space shuttle Atlantis early today, making a successful climb up the International Space Station that was more spacehike than spacewalk.    Dr. Edward Lu and Col. Yuri Malenchenko made...
results.lead_paragraph: An American astronaut and a Russian cosmonaut drifted out of the space shuttle Atlantis early today, making a successful climb up the International Space Station that was more spacehike than spacewalk. Dr. Edward Lu and Col. Yuri Malenchenko made the grueling ascent to lay cable and install a boom for a navigation unit on the exterior of the 140-foot station during their 6-hour, 14-minute spacewalk. They carried the bundled cables on their backs, along with the boom and their tools.

results.abstract: Gen Gherman Stepanovich Titov, fighter pilot who in 1961 became second Russian to fly in space and first man to sleep there, dies at 65; photo (M)

headline.main: Gherman Titov, 65, Second In Quest to Be First in Space

results.snippet: Gen. Gherman Stepanovich Titov, a fighter pilot who in 1961 became the second Russian to fly in space and the first man to sleep there, died on Wednesday while taking a sauna in his apartment here, officials said today.    He turned 65 on Sept. 10....
results.lead_paragraph: Gen. Gherman Stepanovich Titov, a fighter pilot who in 1961 became the second Russian to fly in space and the first man to sleep there, died on Wednesday while taking a sauna in his apartment here, officials said today. He turned 65 on Sept. 10. Initial reports said he died of carbon-monoxide poisoning.

results.abstract: George Nissen, who invented trampoline 64 years ago, is on hand in Sydney to watch his recreational toy transformed into Olympic sport; Irina Karavaeva of Russia wins gold medal in women's Trampoline; Oxana Tsyhuleva of Ukraine wins silver and Karen Cockburn of Canada takes bronze; photo (M)

headline.main: As a Proud Inventor Watches, Acrobatic Participants Christen a New Sport

results.snippet: Sixty-four years ago, George Nissen, an accomplished tumbler and diver, watched a circus trapeze artist drop safely into a net and ricochet back.    He went home, gathered some scrap metal from a bed frame, grabbed a long piece of conveyor-belt...
results.lead_paragraph: Sixty-four years ago, George Nissen, an accomplished tumbler and diver, watched a circus trapeze artist drop safely into a net and ricochet back. He went home, gathered some scrap metal from a bed frame, grabbed a long piece of conveyor-belt material and hooked a few used bedsprings to the sides. When the springs failed to provide the elasticity he wanted, he cut out the inner tube of worn tires.

results.abstract: Deborah Solomon interviews Ed Harris, who comments on portrayal of artist Jackson Pollock in movie Pollock, centerpiece of 38th New York Film Festival; photo (M)

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 9-24-00: Encounter; Portrayal of the Artist

results.snippet: Our subject today is artistic suffering, and Malibu -- so bronze and sandy, so L.A. -- might seem like an odd place to muse on it. Yet as I sit in Ed Harris's lushly planted yard listening to him talk about Jackson Pollock, it seems quite logical...
results.lead_paragraph: Our subject today is artistic suffering, and Malibu -- so bronze and sandy, so L.A. -- might seem like an odd place to muse on it. Yet as I sit in Ed Harris's lushly planted yard listening to him talk about Jackson Pollock, it seems quite logical that the story of New York bohemia would gravitate toward sunny California. As we know, there are no second acts in American lives. But for those whose first acts are artfully tormented, there is always a movie. ''Pollock'' will have its American premiere next Saturday as the centerpiece of the 38th New York Film Festival. Harris is in the title role, and the picture marks his directing debut. He gives us a Pollock with so much pain beneath his shy exterior that even when he's eating breakfast or buying milk at the grocery store, he appears monumentally doomed.

results.abstract: Sally Ride, first woman to become American astronaut, resigns as president of Space.com (S)

headline.main: Metro Business; Sally Ride Leaves Dot-Com

results.snippet: Sally Ride, the first woman who was an American astronaut, resigned on Tuesday as president of Space.com, a year after she joined the company, a Manhattan multimedia publishing firm that bundles space-related Web sites and services.    Ms. Ride, a...
results.lead_paragraph: Sally Ride, the first woman who was an American astronaut, resigned on Tuesday as president of Space.com, a year after she joined the company, a Manhattan multimedia publishing firm that bundles space-related Web sites and services. Ms. Ride, a physics professor on leave from the University of California, San Diego, said she was looking to spend more time involved in science education. ''It has been an exciting 15 months, with an exciting company,'' Ms. Ride said in a statement. But she added that she now has ''a chance to put my energies in an area that's fundamentally important to me.''

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Exhibitions include ''Behind the Screen,'' a permanent display with more than 1,000 artifacts that illustrate the...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Exhibitions include ''Behind the Screen,'' a permanent display with more than 1,000 artifacts that illustrate the production, marketing and exhibition of moving images. The set of Monk's Cafe from ''Seinfeld'' is on display. ''Ride Lonesome: A Budd Boetticher Retrospective,'' through Sunday. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''The Rise and Fall of Legs Diamond'' (1960); at 4 p.m., ''Buchanan Rides Alone'' (1958) and ''The Long Shadow'' (1961). Sunday at 2 p.m., ''The Tall T'' (1957), featuring a dialogue with the filmmaker; at 5 p.m., ''Comanche Station'' (1960), introduced by Mr. Boetticher. ''Repertory Nights: New Prints of Classic Movies,'' tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Roman Polanski's ''Chinatown'' (1974). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.
